name: Ancient Lakes
caption: Valerie Madas, of Seattle, left, and Morgan Kemp, visiting from Illinois, relax after setting up camp at Ancient Lakes. Soak up the Grant County sunshine in coulee country. It’s a great destination for a day hike, or you can camp for the night. (Caitlin Moran)
summary: A day hike to the Columbia Basin is a perfect escape from Western Washington’s fickle spring weather.

name: Baker Lake
caption: Hikers photograph Hidden Creek from a recently repaired bridge on the Baker Lake Trail, in Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest. (Christy Karras photo)
summary: Hikes at this time of year can be tricky: Higher elevations are likely still buried in snow. Fallen trees or rocks may block passage. But here’s an easy hike with smashing views of an iconic North Cascades mountain.

name: Bandera Mountain
caption: Christopher Solomon, of Seattle, looks down on a lake from the Bandera Mountain trail, off Interstate 90 west of Snoqualmie Pass. From the crowded-on-weekends Ira Spring Trail trailhead, hardy hikers who make it up the steep trail to Bandera’s summit might leave crowds behind. (Tan Vinh / The Seattle Times)
summary: From a crowded trailhead just off Interstate 90, butt-kicker climb to summit thins out the tenderfoot hikers.

name: Camano Island Cranberry Lake Trail
caption: Cranberry Lake, in Cama Beach State Park, was created when beavers dammed a small stream. (Brian J. Cantwell / The Seattle Times)
summary: Take an easy hike to a beaver pond teeming with wildlife, then kick back with a cold one at a new outpost of a favorite Seattle brewery.

name: Carbon River Road
caption: Two hikers cross a section of the Carbon River Road that now is a segment of the Carbon River. Foot and bike traffic are the only means of transportation through the Carbon River entrance to the national park. (Erika Schultz / The Seattle Times)
summary: New ‘Creaky Knees’ guide focuses on national parks and monuments

name: Deception Pass
caption: Adam Carlstrom watches as his daughter Maddie Carlstrom, 16, takes a photo from Goose Rock, one of the highest points on Whidbey Island. (Caitlin Moran / The Seattle Times)
summary: Weave under a historic bridge and clamber atop Goose Rock, then finish the day in the Skagit Valley’s new outpost of Chuckanut Brewery.

name: Dungeness Spit
caption: Beach walkers admire the view as they depart Dungeness Spit, a 5.5 walk with a lighthouse (not visible in picture) at the end, Thursday, Sept. 16, 2004. The Dungeness Crab & Seafood Festival, held Oct. 9-10, will be not too far away, in Port Angeles. (Photo by Ken Lambert / The Seattle Times)
summary: Dungeness Spit hike offers dramatic views of water and mountains, and Chimacum’s bucolic Finnriver Cidery is a perfect spot to wind down.

name: Goose Rock
caption: lorem

name: Grand Forest Trails
caption: Bainbridge Island, Wa - 04/25/2013 - 129339 - gg  - Bainbridge Island resident Helen Hendrickson enjoys the sunlight filtering through the tall trees in Bainbridge Island's Grand Forest. (Greg Gilbert / The Seattle Times)
summary: Embrace the rain and enjoy uncrowded time in the forest.

name: John Tursi Trail
caption: lorem
summary: Deception Pass is our most-visited state park, but you can find solitude if you know where to look.

name: Kukutali Preserve
caption: lorem
summary: Deception Pass is our most-visited state park, but you can find solitude if you know where to look.

name: Lake Ingalls Trail
caption: Lake Ingalls is good for fly casting because of its lack of surrounding vegetation. (Kyle Johnson)
summary: Washington’s high lakes offer fresh scenery, and you might be the only angler on the water.

name: Lime Kiln Trail
caption: Jake Hoffman, left, and Tyler Godwin check out the historical lime kiln from which this hike receives its name. (Evan Bush / The Seattle Times)
summary: A close-to-home cruiser of a hike winds through a moist forest and leads to relics of the past.

name: Middle Fork Snoqualmie River
caption: MIDDLE FORK AREA OF THE SNOQUALMIE RIVER - NORTH BEND - 053012(Stitched Image)    Mark Boyar surveys the Middle Fork Snoqualmie Park Natural Area including Russian Butte in the distance from a bluff near the 7 mile CCC trail which winds it's way through the Natural Area. One of the closest and prettiest trips for hikers is getting better with a paved access road and new trail to enjoy on the Mid Fork Snoqualmie.   121167 (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: Embrace the rain and enjoy uncrowded time in the forest.

name: Oyster Dome Trail
caption: Magdalena Theisen (left) high-fives Ewa Klosek after they and Barbara Timofiejuk climbed to the top of Oyster Dome. Klosek and Timofiejuk, from Poland, were visiting Thiesen. (Andy Bronson Photography)
summary: Improvements include new switchbacks on a formerly steeper and slippery stretch of trail overlooking Samish Bay and the San Juans.

name: Pacific Crest Trail
caption: Lupine, Indian paintbrush and western bistort fill a meadow in the Goat Rocks Wilderness as 12,276-foot Mount Adams dominates the southern horizon. (Terry Wood)
summary: The national scenic trail’s northern leg offers some of its grandest views. Here are some trail veterans’ favorite stretches.

name: Silver Falls
caption: HIGHWAY 410 ROAD TRIP - MT. RAINIER - 092111Silver Falls on the Ohanapecosh River just off of Highway 123. Travel section story about a fall road trip up Highway 410. (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: New ‘Creaky Knees’ guide focuses on national parks and monuments

name: Spruce Railroad Trail
caption: Hikers pause along the Spruce Railroad Trail edging Lake Crescent, in Olympic National Park. (Seabury Blair Jr.)
summary: New ‘Creaky Knees’ guide focuses on national parks and monuments

name: Tiger Mountain Talus Rocks
caption: NEED CORRECT PHOTO
summary: Embrace the rain and enjoy uncrowded time in the forest.

name: Twin Falls
caption: One portion of Twin Falls is observed from an overlook above the Snoqualmie River. The trailhead is east of North Bend, off Interstate 90. (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: Embrace the rain and enjoy uncrowded time in the forest.

name: Umtanum Ridge Crest Trail
caption: Central Washington University students Joey Cotto, Jimmy Brakka, Sheldon Liikala and Harrison Danna hoof up the dusty Umtanum Ridge Crest trail. (Evan Bush/The Seattle Times)
summary: A straightforward, short and steep hike that offers beautiful views of volcanoes and wildflowers, the Umtanum Ridge Crest Trail is worth a sweaty slog through sunny canyonlands near the Yakima River.

name: Wallace Falls
caption: Fungus grows from a mossy tree trunk along a trail in Wallace Falls State Park, just north of Gold Bar, off Highway 2. (Mike Siegel / The Seattle Times)
summary: Embrace the rain and enjoy uncrowded time in the forest.

name: Wenatchee Crest snowshoe
caption: Wenatchee Crest trail, located at Blewett Pass on the Cascades’ sunny side, has minimal elevation gain and follows an old dirt road, making it a good choice for first-time snowshoers. (Caitlin Moran / The Seattle Times)
summary: A leisurely snowshoe hike and a brewery visit are the perfect way to shake off the winter blues.

name: Westside Road
caption: NEW PHOTO?
summary: New ‘Creaky Knees’ guide focuses on national parks and monuments

name: Wonderland Trail
